title: US private equity group expected to raise offer for UDG Healthcare
text:
UDG Healthcare said it expects to receive a sweetened takeover offer from buyout firm Clayton, Dubilier & Rice that would value the drugs industry outsourcer at around £2.9bn.

CD&R has indicated it is considering raising its takeover offer to £10.80 a share, UDG said. The Dublin-based company, which last month indicated it had agreed an £10.23 all-cash offer, said that it intends to recommend the improved final offer if it is made.

UDG's plans to sell itself have met with opposition from investors including Allianz Global Investors, its largest shareholder, and M&G Investments. Elliott Investment Management, the activist investor and merger arbitrage specialist, said last month it had taken a stake in the company. 

To allow for the improved offer UDG said it plans to adjourn a shareholder meeting scheduled for today. The company added that since revealing CD&R's offer it had not received any other bid approaches.

Briefly

The Competition and Markets Authority said it has opened a formal probe into Amazon and Google over concerns that they have not been doing enough to combat fake reviews on their sites. The regulator, which opened its investigation of online fake reviews in May 2020, said it will gather further information to determine whether these two companies may have broken consumer law by taking insufficient action to protect shoppers.

Marshall Motor, the car dealership franchise operator, said it expects to report an “exceptionally strong first half performance in both profit and cash generation”. Full-year underlying pre-tax profit will be significantly ahead of current market expectations thanks to the recent unprecedented used vehicle value appreciation and favourable demand-to-supply conditions for both new and used vehicles, it said.

Freight management group Xpediator hiked full-year targets to reflect positive first-half trading trends. The Aim-quoted company said that strong trading across all its divisions meant it was on track to deliver a full-year adjusted pre-tax profit in excess of £8.5m.

EE is to bring back roaming charges for new UK customers travelling in Europe, becoming the first mobile operator to reintroduce the fee since Brexit. The BT Group-owned company said customers joining after July 7 would from January be charged £2 a day to use their data, voice or text allowances in the EU.

Job moves

Drinks maker AG Barr named former Dairy Crest chief executive Mark Allen as its chair designate from next month, succeeding John Nicolson, who steps down after seven years in the role.

Beyond the Square Mile

The Federal Reserve has further loosened restrictions on dividends and buybacks imposed on the biggest US banks during Covid-19, as it released an analysis showing lenders could suffer almost $500bn in losses and still comfortably meet capital requirements.

Toshiba shareholders voted against the reappointment of Osamu Nagayama, the chair of the Japanese company's board, in the wake of a report into alleged government collusion.

Google has delayed a plan to end support for third-party cookies in its Chrome browser by nearly two years. The search engine said it was holding off to allow more time for discussion with regulators and companies involved in digital advertising, and to “avoid jeopardising the business models of many web publishers which support freely available content”.

Raisin and Deposit Solutions, two of Germany's largest fintechs and fierce rivals, have struck a merger aimed at creating a pan-European group that links banks with depositors. The combined company, which will be called Raisin DS and headquartered in Berlin, will have about 400 banking partners and more than 500 employees.

Hedge funds that bet on falling share prices are stepping up efforts to spot the next GameStop, after this year's “meme stock” bonanza left the industry nursing billions of dollars of losses in just six months.

Essential comment before you go

Bryce Elder
But for the venue, there's nothing remarkable about currency transfer company Wise's plans for a direct listing. Celebrating its choice of London for the float should not be allowed to deflect scrutiny of the business and its management.

City Insider
